Title: Index of Medieval Medical Images
Description.abstract: The Index of Medieval Medical Images project began in 1988 and aimed to describe and index the content of all medieval manuscript images (up to the year 1500) with medical components held in North American collections. The goal of this 2001 pilot project was to make a substantial sample of the images and descriptions available via a searchable database on the Web.

Title: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript. 25 (Guy de Chauliac. Chirurgia).
Description.abstract: Completed in 1476 at Luterback, Switzerland, this manuscript of the Chirurgia of the French physician Guy de Chauliac (ca. 1300-1368) includes drawings of surgical instruments in red, blue, and black. Manuscript owned by the National Library of Medicine (U.S.).

Title: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript. 78. [Isagoge ad Tegni Galeni and other medical texts].
Description.abstract: Written at Oxford, England, in the 13th century, this compilation gathers basic introductions to classical medicine, two of them by the important 9th century Arabic translator, Johannitius (H?unayn ibn Ish?a¯q al-?Iba¯di, 809?-873) and one possibly by the famous Robert Grosseteste, Bishop of Lincoln (1175?-1253). Also included are the Aphorisms of Hippocrates and two works by Theophilos Protospatharios (7th century). Historiated initials depict uroscopy, diagnosis, a pregnant woman, instructional scenes, and medical authors. Manuscript owned by the National Library of Medicine (U.S.)

Title: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Manuscript.  9 [John Arderne. Opera chirurgica].
Description.abstract: Written in England about 1400, mainly in Latin, NLM MS 9 (Opera chirurgica) contains excerpts from the medical, surgical, and ophthalmologic works of John Arderne  (fl. 1307-1370). Sketches attempt to illustrate Arderne's treatments for fistula in ano, and his comments on other practical and theoretical medical and surgical issues. Manuscript owned by the National Library of Medicine (U.S.).

Title: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Incunabula. Schullian 274 (Copulator super tres libros Aristotelis. De anima doctrinam Thomae de Aquino)
Description.abstract: Printed book (Cologne: D. Molner, 1485) containing a manuscript image dated 1497. Image is a diagram listing the main locations of cognitive function. Book owned by the National Library of Medicine (U.S.).

Title: National Library of Medicine  (U.S.). Incunabula. Schullian 379 (Positiones circa libros Physicorum et De anima Aristotelis).
Description.abstract: Printed book (Cologne: Heinrich Quentell, 1494) containing a manuscript image dated ca. 1500. Image is a diagram listing the main locations of cognitive and sensory functions and their relation to some organs of the thorax. Book owned by the National Library of Medicine (U.S.).

Title: Rosenbach Museum and Library. Manuscript. Rosenbach 1004/29. [Physician's belt book]
Description.abstract: Believed to have been copied at York, in the north of England, about 1364, this "belt book" (a finger-tip reference work in the form of a small fan of folded parchment) includes two visual guides to treatment. The first image facilitated therapy by indicating points at which the practitioner could effectively tap his patient's blood. The second image is designed to help the physician make a diagnosis by analyzing the color of a patient's urine. Owned by the Rosenbach Museum and Library.

Title: University of California, Los Angeles. Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. Manuscript. Benjamin Collection 10 [Medical collectanea, 2].
Description.abstract: In Latin and Czech and written in several hands about 1450,  probably in Prague, this medical miscellany includes a full-page image of a bloodletting man and one figure of a male body extending over 4 pages. Simple sketches of urine flasks also appear. Manuscript owned by the Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

Title: University of California, Los Angeles. Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. Manuscript. Benjamin Collection 3. [Single leaf from Bernard of Gordon's Tractatus de conservatione vitae humanae].
Description.abstract: Written in French during the 14th century, perhaps in Paris, this single leaf from Bernard of Gordon's Tractatus de conservatione vitae humanae, an academic treatise on common medical practices, includes a fine historiated initial introducing the subject of the section on diagnosing with urines. Manuscript owned by the Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

Title: University of California, Los Angeles. Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. Manuscript. Benjamin Collection 5. [Fuer das Urin oder Stein].
Description.abstract: Written in German about 1350, probably in Germany, this treatise includes a traditional urine wheel chart for diagnosing with urines on the basis of color. Captioned in Latin and carefully tinted with watercolor, the circular diagram has been cut into pieces and pasted into the German text. Manuscript owned by the Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library
Title: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Manuscript. Arm. ms.1 [Glajor Gospel]
Description.abstract: Written and illustrated during the first decade of the 14th century at the Glajor monastery, most likely in the Elegec valley of Armenia, the Glajor Gospel portrays major events of the New Testament. It is part of the last flowering of artistic culture in independent pre-modern Armenia. Selected illustrations depict medical conditions including epilepsy, skin disease, paralysis, and blindness. Manuscript is owned by the University of California, Los Angeles.

Title: University of Vermont. Library. MS 2. [Italian herbal]
Description.abstract: Completed between 1475 and 1525 in Italy, possibly in Tuscany, Vermont MS 2 provides an unusual example of a late illustrated manuscript herbal. Dramatic angel and demon figures indicate benevolent and destructive properties in the plants depicted and sometimes appear to comment on the diseases being treated.  Scenes include the administration of an enema, and portrayals of sufferers from skin lesions, inflammations, and gynecological problems. Manuscript is owned by the University of Vermont Library.
Description.note: Script: Written in two scripts. Primary script is a small but bold, vertical Cursiva with un-looped ascenders. Secondary script is a lighter, sloping cursive with looped ascenders. There are added drawings and notes on many leaves, including several versos.|~|Physical description: Layout: Unruled. Most versos are blank. Decoration: Illustrations are found on each folio, and are of medicinal herbs, of the medical conditions they treat, and of their application and effects. They often employ symbolism. Colors include dark green, blue-green, dark brown, dark red, dark blue, flesh-colored, golden brown, and orange-red. Pictures decorate the lower margins of fols. 17, 19, 50, 58, and 59.|~|Binding: Not bound. Manuscript was disbound from its late 18th c. binding in 1992. Individual leaves were dry cleaned and encapsulated in polyester film at that time.
Relation.isPartOf: Medieval and Renaissance Manuscripts Collection (University of Vermont Libraries)|~|http://cdi.uvm.edu/collections/item/mrmc002
AltTitle.other: Colixoge chavolo idem est, questa e una pianta asai conosciuta

Name.repository: Harvey Cushing/John Hay Whitney Medical Library
Title: Yale Medical Library. Manuscript. 18 [Herbarium Apuleii and other works].
Description.abstract: Produced in Lombardy about 1400, Yale Medical Library Ms. 18 is a late illustrated example of a very traditional herbal, a group of texts sometimes called the Herbarius complex, the origins of which go back to the 4th century.  It became the most widely used of all anthologies on materia medica available in the early Middle Ages. One of the texts, "Ex herbis feminis," based on Dioscorides, was illustrated at least as early as the sixth century, judging from the admonition of  Cassiodorus "if you do not have sufficient facility reading Greek, then you can turn to the herbal of Dioscorides, which describes and draws the herbs of the field with wonderful  faithfulness." (The original work of Dioscorides was, of course in Greek and not illustrated.)  That work, the Herbarius of Pseudo-Apuleius, which gives its name to the complex, and the Liber medicinae ex animalibus et avibus attributed to Sextus Placitus, contain the bulk of the illustrations.  These consist mostly of plant and animal portraits, bold and attractively tinted, but also include several authorial portraits, a few harvesting scenes, consultation scenes, and cityscapes. In addition, some interesting mythological scenes appear in the Precationes (Precatio terrae and Precatio omnium herbarum), lightly Christianized pagan prayers to the powers of the earth and of its herbs. Manuscript owned by the Yale Medical Library.

Name.repository: Harvey Cushing/John Hay Whitney Medical Library
Title: Yale Medical Library. Manuscript. 28 [Paneth codex].
Description.abstract: Completed in Bologna in 1326, the Paneth codex is a large heavy volume, likely used as a university reference book. It contains 42 medical tracts by both classical and contemporary authorities, including Hippocrates, Galen, and Rhazes (Ra?zi?, Abu? Bakr Muhòammad ibn Zakari?ya?, 865?-925?). Veterinary medicine is addressed in works on falconry and the care of horses. The subject of surgery dominates, with more than one quarter of the manuscript devoted to four surgical tracts including one by Albucasis (Abu? Al-Qa?sim Khalaf ibn Abba?s al-Zahra?wi?, d. 1013?),which is illustrated with images of surgical instruments. Nearly 50 miniatures and illustrated initials depict scenes of instruction, physicians attending the sick and bedridden, and medical practices including taking the pulse, bloodletting, uroscopy, and head surgery. Detailed and colorful marginalia include geometric patterns and anthropomorphic figures that appear sometimes to comment humorously on the subjects of the miniatures and initials. Forty-one tables explicate the regimens of Ibn Butlan's Tacuinum sanitatis. The Paneth codex is owned by Yale University.
